questions.text: What is the primary purpose of 'Normalization (Min-Max Scaling)'?

options.text: To transform data to have a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1.
To remove noise from time series data.
To scale numerical features to a fixed range, typically [0, 1].
To group continuous data into discrete bins.

questions.explanation: Normalization (Min-Max Scaling) rescales features to a specific range, most commonly [0, 1].

questions.text: Standardization (Z-score Scaling) is highly sensitive to outliers.
questions.explanation: Standardization is generally less sensitive to outliers compared to Min-Max scaling because it uses the mean and standard deviation, which are themselves affected by outliers but don't define the bounds of the transformation as min/max values do.

questions.text: Which of the following are examples of 'Data Generalization'? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Replacing an age of '32' with an 'Adult' category.
Calculating the sum of sales for each region.
Converting specific city names like 'New York', 'Los Angeles' to a broader 'USA' category.
Applying a log transformation to a skewed numerical feature.

questions.explanation: Data generalization involves replacing specific values with broader categories or concepts. Aggregation (like sum of sales) is a summarization, and log transformation is a value transformation, not generalization in this context.
